place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text: Tons of trails (12 miles!) through woods and wetland. Lots of opportunities for bird watching. Easy-going trails with benches scattered about and an observation tower, featuring a great view over a swamp. 7 dollar fee for non-members - definitely worth it!

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text: This is one of my favorite places to go! You can go for a walk, bird watch, feed the birds, and just enjoy the variety of trails and sights to see. I will always recommend this wildlife sanctuary!

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text:
A beautiful park for a short easy strolling through forest and on riverside walks. A LOT of birds! Well maintained paths. There is an entrance fee, though, if not a member of Mass Audubon.
Winter (without snow) forest & ponds were beautiful, will try other seasons.

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text:
Great place to see birds with nice trails along the coastal marshlands. I only had about an hour, but still got to see a bunch of different birds up close including a hawk. Parts of the trail were submerged after a rainy week, but the views were still amazing.

Admission fee was $7 for adults and $4 for kids.

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text: Nice area to walk but some of the main trails aren't cleared well and you end up in grassy and muddy areas. My daughter loves it here for the bird watching and feeding the chickadees so we continue to go during spring and summer. The bathrooms are pretty clean and that's a plus.

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text:
Wonderful place for trails and bird wildlife.
My kids loved it

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text:
BRING BIRD SEED WITH YOU.
Absolute favorite place for a walk. I get to explore so many natural feature and species. Give me a love for birds every time I go here. Special place with long history of many generations of tons of bird species. The birds have been extra friendly here throughout generations. It's hard to find that anywhere else.
Take a big loop. Go on trails with less people. Explore. More chances to have a bird feed of your hand

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text: Expansive grounds with woods, fields, pond, river and varying terrain. I went with my husband who tires easily and had his walker with a seat. We followed Bradstreet and Drumlin trails. Parts were a little rocky for the wheels of the walker but he managed. We were unable though to take any of the side trails to see some of the better sights due to rougher ground or inclines. There were benches along the trail to rest. We saw many birds and had little ones eating birdseed from our hands. Very peaceful and enjoyable.

This is a gorgeous place staffed by incredibly friendly people. Worth every single penny of the annual membership.

Supporting this organization helps keep our drinking water clean and safe, local ecology protected, and gives you boating access to this beautiful river. Do it!
response_from_owner_text: Thanks, Sean! Glad to have you as a member :)

review_text: Incredible Gem in the heart of the North Shore.  Great organization with a dedicated team working hard to save our most important asset. Spread the word and donate what you can.
Great place for a canoe or kayak! They do great work for the watershed too, so get a membership and get paddling :)
Beautiful spot for paddling. Juat watch river levels, as it's tough to paddle in some spots during a drought.
response_from_owner_text: Thanks, Jen! Yes, drought conditions sadly impact paddling. Please consider taking the Greenscapes Water for People pledge at greenscapes.org/waterforpeople and getting a free lawn sign to help spread the word about water conservation.

review_text: Planning to Kayak there this summer.
Great place to go for a day out. Lots of wildlife, fresh air, and quiet from urban jungles.
Lovely, small piece of land. Staff was very friendly and helpful. Would go back.
Great organization...... They have a free boat launch duck in the river here

Obviously the best part of the river runs thru Ipswich proper. A diverse river offering lazy paddle opportunities above the downtown dam at Ebsco to the extreme tidal currents at her mouth there is something for everyone. Caution: deranged beaver have been known to attack kayakers.
A lovely waterway for kayak or canoeing. Charming, the way it snakes through the towns
Nice clean park. Not sure how good the fishing is or how well stocked it is. Heard or saw a lot of songbirds / wildlife. Wish there was a baby changing station. If there was one, it wasn't obvious.

It's probably one of the best parks around. Baseball field, basketball, playground, tennis, nice walking trail, street hockey court, and a big Field to do whatever. There is also a skate park. The park is dog friendly and really great for all ages. They're is a snack shack in the summer with bathrooms. Vending machines are there year round.
Nice park , silent, good for kids and who loves nature. Small river. Free parking. No firing system
Great place to take your pup for a walk and let them wade in the river
Such a beautiful clean park. Very kind neighborhood area to get here. Dog walk path available,  disabled Community accessible,  Tennis court. Some places between trees you can hike too.. fun fun.
Love this local park! Open fields, walking path, river, tennis, basketball, clean restrooms and more. It is beautifully maintained! Thanks North Reading.

Went there for a birthday party rented one of the canopies very clean atmosphere.. Lawn was kept up and the field was large. Nice park for the kids outdoor hockey rink skateboard area. The only downside was the parking was pretty far from our birthday party.

One of my favorite places to hang out or walk around. A very pretty park, usually some people there but not too crowded. Lots of amenities including a playground, water fountain, tennis and basketball courts, street hockey rink, soccer field, and picnic tables. Fun events like farmers markets and concerts every so often.

A great place for all to come and enjoy. Pick rifie, pistol, archery, or trap. Plenty options. The indoor archery range is great to use. Great group of people here. A growing club that is a mix of men and women. Trap Leagues, annual barbecues, constant training.
Nice small club with Trap, Rifle and Pistol ranges,  archery and a fish pond. Members only on property. Memberships available at monthly meeting, 7:00pm first Monday of the month.

Super friendly group of people.  A great place to learn archery and all types of guns.  Most facilities are out of doors and well maintained.  The clubhouse is clean and has a function area and a kitchen upstairs and a short archery range in the basement.  One of the best deals in the New England area.
Good place for archery ( kids and adults ) everything else is OK. The thing is they are all open air facilities ( think of rain, snow, sun and bugs). However very friendly folks.

Been a great experience, have been a shooter and hunter for 35 years and never been a member of a club.Mostly not liking the way they run things and what is involved in becoming a member I never joined one.I was impressed with Ipswich fish and game from the beginning and I liked the facility it's all you need to hone in on your skills from archery,pistol,rifle etc. Good people and nice clean facility.
Safe and friendly

We didn't actually plan on coming here. There was hardly any parking at Plum Island, so I looked for public parking, which led us to this little paradise. It's just $5 to enter and park, cash only. There are around eight parking lots throughout the park. Some don't have beach access and are meant for the trails, but there are restrooms at some of the lots.

The first beach access point was pretty crowded and seemed to be the most popular spot. However, if you travel further down, you'll discover various wildlife trails. We stopped and walked the Hellcat Interpretive Trail, which offered natural shade and a clean, well-built boardwalk. Make sure to bring bug spray! We had some in the car thankfully. Then we drove all the way down to the end to Sandy Point. After a certain point, the road transitions from paved to gravel.

The beach was lovely! The water was clear and pristine, and the sand was soft. There were barely any people around. I always keep a beach tent and towels in the back of my car, so we set those up, laid out, and took a nap. I was in awe--how could this whole experience cost only $5?

Sometimes, when things don't work out--like discovering Plum Island has no parking for visitors--you end up somewhere even better <3

This place is very nice. Hard to get there, it takes 17 minutes of driving in wilderness, and the last 5 minutes driving on a not paved road on gravel in clouds of dust from all the other cars in front of you. When you finally get to the parking, you realize, that there are no free spots, cause the lot is extremely small, like for 10 cars only. You have to wait in a huge line, if you are lucky, you get the spot. The beach is beautiful, we came to a low tide. On the other side of the water you can see the edge of the estate of Castle Hill on Crane Estate in Ipswich.

We had a lovely walk here on the sand at low tide. Lots and lots of sand and interesting waves that were coming in perpendicular to the shore rather than parallel something I had never seen before. There is abroad expanse of sand for easy walking but also lots of good rocks for scrambling and plentiful shells if you have kids who enjoy collecting them. Despite the fact that it was 50deg in February, there was almost no one here, probably because it's such a long drive down plum Island to get there.

Located on the southern end of Plum Island, it truly is a gem of a spot. At low tide, ideal for kids playing in tidal pools. Nice Sandy beach. Outhouse at parking area. Small parking lot fills up quickly(lot of empty spots at 9 am Tuesday on July 18, 2023). Buy a season pass at the gate house (annual is $20). They will post signs if Sandy Point is filled, allowing you entrance to the major beach just on the left. Other beaches and parking areas are closed during bird nesting periods. Good nature trails and bird observation platforms. Green heads were a problem for us, even with a wind. Expect your auto to get dusty as the last several miles are packed gravel. Bring an extra bag and feel free to pick-up plastic and other debris that has washed ashore or discarded which is deadly to marine and animal life.
We visited P.I again for a picnic on March 13, 2024 and met an aspiring gymnast as seen here. Two vids taken from an observation tower on the way to Sandy Point.

What a beautiful area and great spot for a bike ride. Got to Sandy Point about 7am having ridden from downtown Newburyport.  The road is gravel the last 3 miles till the end with the last quarter mile being very potholed.  Lots of people bird watching but did not see anyone out on the beach. Would recommend to anyone to visit.

Great beach to spend quality time with family and friends. Parking is a bit tricky; plan ahead and arrive early. Wish I could give this a 5 star, but the staff is rude and unprofessional. One of the rangers at the Sandy Point parking lot told us to park at a spot. We came back to the car about 45 minutes later and gave us a ticket for parking there. The guy denied that he allowed us to park there, but he was the one who redirected us (there was no signs of No Parking either). MAKES NO SENSE!! Be careful.

A little chilly today, but the sun was shining and I had a wonderful walk along the beach.  Then, crossing the road, I enjoyed watching the Hawk's and egrets lifting out of the marsh. I have to admit I spent a bit of time feeling nostalgic, looking across the Sound at Crane Beach. We spent many summer days there in my childhood.
Gorgeous beach!! My first trip to New England coast and it was very enjoyable! So pretty and not too busy. I can't wait to visit again.
Pretty place for a stroll but be sure to prep for a muddy walk when it's been wet for a few days. Beautiful views of the salt marshes.
Nice place for a stroll and some marsh views.
Nice short trail for a walk with a dog.
Tasty little jaunt. Beware tick season! Beautiful scenery.
See the salt box all others are measured by or defy death on the antique stream crossings. Dog friendly.
Nice, short, quiet walk in Meadows. Nice views
It's worth to spend all your day here even not enough!
Amazing place, wonderful nature!!!

The pool area is amazing! It's like a small water park, although it's free for use with membership. It has a nice fenced in grassy area for a picnic also. The bathrooms/ changing area are not up to date like the rest of the facility. I tried to hurry as fast as possible in there. It won't determine us from going back for the pool though!

The facilities here are much older than the Beverly and Gloucester YMCAs and could use some updating. The workout area is also much smaller, but gets the job done. The basketball court is nice, the childcare center is good, and they have a great outdoor splash pad and pool in the summer. I've also been to several kids birthday parties here which were nicely done.

I went to the Ipswich Y with my granddaughters (5 and 7) who are also members and we had a great time in the outdoor pool.  Will definitely return.  I normally frequent the Beverly Y, glad to have branched out.  I find the Y has great resources, the staff are friendly and my membership is a great value.

Excellent water park and splash pad! So much fun for kids of all ages! The lifeguards are all friendly and helpful with the kids. There's a rope to climb, and a swing obstacle across the water. There is a small area of deep water for older kids to swim. The slide is a huge hit! It's well kept and clean. The bathrooms are pristine! There's a nice sized family locker room.

This YMCA has some of the kindest, most friendly staff, and they are so helpful with anything you need. Such a cool outdoor pool! And we especially love how family friendly it is, something for all of us to do!

I am so happy my daughter is at the Amesbury YMCA Child Care Center. She is always happy to go to the child care center to see her teachers Ms. Emma and Ms. Megan and friends in the toddler room! Her teachers are amazing and make her feel so welcome and she loves all the activities and she has grown so much over the year!!! Thank you very much for taking such great care of my little girl!!!

Awesome investment in the Ipswich Community. Was completed during my residency from the mid 90's through 2018. My family were members from the get go. Swimming lessons and children's camp options were always fabulous. I loved the ZUMBA classes

For some reason this location is not very comfortable or safe. Been a member here for several years due to the convenience of location but other than that, I'm paying family membership fees as a waste of money as we're not able to utilize everything the Y has to offer.

Excellent place to skate. Friendly Bat Heads are unusual north of Boston. All park goers are Nice to skaters one and all.

Be respectful when you're there. Clean up when you go home. Smile. That's all you gotta do to be excepted by this lovely community

I should move here

This park is going to be sweet! Kudos to the group of people that were able to put this together. Make sure you buy your kid a skateboard as an early Christmas gift this year so he can start skating this park ASAP!
Good old community funded skatepark. Can't wait to see this place grow.
Great for begginers, first drop ins, etc. I've grown out of it but so great.
Fun little park..
We went on the Willowdale Run and had a lovely time. The water was very calm and there were areas of shad to escape the sun.  The staff were very kind and helpful. We can't wait to go back!

This is a hidden gem of the local area. The Ipswich river inconspicuously snakes it's way through the quaint country communities of Ipswich, Hamilton, Topsfield and Middleton. However, in the Ipswich and Topsfield section and where Foote Brothers Canoes operates, the river passes through the large conservation areas of Bradley Palmer State Park, Willowdale State Forest and the National Audubon Society's wildlife sanctuary. These three conservation zones converge to create a large wildlife reserve, much of which can only be accessed by water. Foote Brother's convenient shuttle drops you upstream where you can drift down through the entirety of the wildlife reserve back to their facility.

In an increasingly busy world, finding places of quiet to enjoy the sights and sounds of nature while slipping along silently on calm waters, is a rarity. Foote Brothers was founded as a family business and has remained so for more then half a century. They are involved in the public school system to provide educational trips for school children, they are active in conservation efforts and they are well known and loved generationally by the local communities.

We did the cheaper option to take off from the center and paddle upstream as far as we could and then downstream. Two in my party were beginners so in the future we'll do the more expensive and get dropped off and do the 3.5 hour paddle downstream. Only downside is the traffic that goes along the river. I wish we didn't hear the cars. Very friendly and will come back!

Cyrus and his family are so nice to fellow paddlers! On our own paddle not using any of his gear we portaged the dam in front of Footies. Immediately afterwards there was a large log jam that sucked in one of our kayaks. In the chaos we lost a paddle. I hiked through the woods to Footies and Cyrus was more than happy to lend us one to get down river to our final destination.
Thank you so much! I would highly recommend this business!
I enjoyed canoeing here. 50$ for one canoe. They provide paddles and safety jackets.

Easy, no-fuss kayak rental. Staff was happy to answer all my questions in a very patient way. The staff went above and beyond helping me out when I had a snafu. Fabulous service & amazing location. Can't wait to go back again this summer!
Their crew of employees are great at assisting you to shore.  I visit here often & you'll love it too.
We didnt rent however, always friendly staff and willing to help you either way. Stay safe. Great day on the river. You can get kayak and canoe rentals there too

It's short but interesting.   You might be able to squeak out one mile. There is a plaque there describing the old gardens that were there in the early 1900s. On the trail, you can look for the remnants of some structures, and it's pretty interesting. Right along the Ipswich River, you pass along the IRWA canoe launch.  A quiet, low traffic area canoe spot, and we are now likely to become members to take advantage of this hidden gem. (No tourists in sight)
Assisted living establishment.  U can visit there and go for Jazz Brunch once a month
Short but sweet. State of the art small watercraft launching [in season].

I was wondering about the availability of public access this same day on the 1st of September' when I was visiting the Meadow and Salt Marsh at Strawberry Hill. Now I know more since you made your post. Since this is a recognized ACEC Environmental Protection Site. I am in the future' planning to visit Sandy Point State Reservation Beach, across Plum Island Sound as a result of the environmental restriction. The publicly accessible State Reservation Beach is also in the Town of Ipswich within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Plenty to enjoy!
This is private property. No public beach access or parking!
This is NOT a public beach!
No public parking.
Handy place to park for canoe or kayak launch on the Ipswich. Also good starting point for walking on the rail trail.
Can walk from here on the trails.  Long flat, kinda boring walk, but no traffic and peaceful.   Also a good place to throw a canoe into the river from.

This stretch of the Ipswich River toward the Audubon sanctuary is unparalleled in its beauty and variety for river kayaking.  This is also a good place to park for the bike path that also crosses here.
Easy put in, pleasant paddle through wooded banks. Notable current and high water this time
Easy parking, slight downhill launch into shallow water.
Limited parking but terrific place to put in
The best
Quiet time.
Watch for a small sign signifying the trail head. Park on the side of the road and go enjoy the silence of a forest with birds.

Very quiet and pretty except when there's a polo game. Nice for walking and horseback riding. Also it's ok when Appleton trails are open to park your horse trailer here, and Appleton is just across the street. (Polo may scare horses that aren't used to it, though.)

It has a pleasingly diverse array of ecotones woven through an Essex County horse farm with an old polo field. There is a good web of trails. It's relatively small size make it a good spot for a toddler hike especially for children interested in horses.

The trail along the river is a favorite because of the kame terrace banks amid a conifer grove. Ideal times are spring migration and fall color.
Hidden gem. Unique, high banked views of the Ipswich River. Flat trails with virtually no elevation change. Very wet in the spring and watch out for horse traffic.
Parking for several cars. Nice flat trail. Views of Ipswich River, horses, polo field. Tall pines.
Wonderful trails along the river and historic property.
Flat and short. Nice little walk along the Ipswich River.
Beautiful greenway with some nice views of the Ipswich River.

I have mountain biked here many times over the years. This time, I was here to walk the trails. I enjoy taking the trail that leads you down along the Ipswitch River. If you stay on that path, you will come to a few small dams with waterfalls. There is also this awesome fish ladder built back in the 1930s and still in use today.

Willows, dales and mills - this reservation has it all. Dog friendly, which is nice. Follows the river on relatively flat terrain. Easy to cross into the maze of the larger park trail system, best to bring a charged phone.The bridge on the access road is in need of repair so take it slowly.
Excellent trails that aren't crowded.
Beautiful place
Great place
Waterfall.
I was in a canoe going down the Ipswich River before
Was here a week ago and it's truly a must see. Staff was very knowledgeable and helpful. Includes the earliest, best preserved home in America from c.1677, the Whipple House. Well done!
response_from_owner_text: Thank you for the kind words, Tom! Glad you enjoyed the visit.

review_text: If the day is too hot, 94f the day I was there,  the Castle Hill house was closed due to being too hot inside.

I came to Ipswich because, like many others, I could trace my roots to the early settlers. I stumbled into this museum hoping for a glimpse of what my ancestors experienced. I got far more than that! The staff were incredibly knowledgeable and so eager to share. They explained things in a way that was easy to follow and understand and were open to answering all the questions I had. They were welcoming and kind and so helpful. They even helped me pinpoint where my ancestors lived and gave me directions to find them. I took the tour of the homes and it was a profound experience to feel that close to my past. I would highly recommend the museum and tour for anyone remotely interested in learning more about the history of Ipswich. If Bob is there, ask him about the architecture and Bill can tell you about their lifestyles. It truly is fascinating.

This is a really good museum. Not just an old dusty local-yocal spot, the Heard House is well curated, clean and has a lot to say.

Ipswich, surprisingly enough, has a history that teaches many lessons. E.g., its Chinese exhibits are spectacular in their specificity... Did you know that the first motorized vessel in Asia had its origins in Ipswich? This just one of many cool stories told and shown here. And, there is much more... many of which rhyme with the issues we face today.

The museum is spread out over three houses. My time was limited, so I was only able to visit the Heard House.
Went to research family history but volunteers were very confused and not helpful.  There is more information on the website and historical association books.
loved all the preserved history with the amazing guide!!!
Very friendly & enthusiastic staff!
response_from_owner_text: So glad you enjoyed your time at the museum, Emma! We are lucky to have the volunteers we do.

review_text: Good collection of arts from 19th century and revolutionary war.

A great easy hike, would be good for mountain biking or walking the dog. Mostly flat root exposure not many rocks.  You can make it a quick hike or longer check out the alltrails app. So easy and very convenient.

Drove by this on the way to a customer's house and decided to hike it on the way back. An empty parking area I had all to myself. After applying insect repellent (which is always recommended), I took a picture of the map and headed in not knowing what  to expect and how far I was going. I spent a couple of hours following the trail the took me around the reservoir. It was a nice hike. The weather was not too hot. It was a nice hike with great scenery and the sounds of nature. The mud wasn't too bad. I noticed horseshoe prints in the dirt. I almost stepped on a large black and yellow snake due to looking ahead and not down. I would recommend the trail. It was a long but easy hike.

Well maintained and marked trails, however, high wetness potential. Dog friendly. Connects to the Bay Circuit Trail. If you follow the BCT into Rowley you can climb to the top of Prospect Hill. Rigorous hike, but disappointing vista.
It was pretty muddy so I couldn't explore the whole place. It was quite pretty from the 30 minute hike I took. The place had tons of large ferns! There are about 10 parking spots there.
Trail is NOT marked well. A lot of roots at begining of trail.

Dow brook has established trails for walking, jogging or biking. There are a few downed branches but overall the path is clear.  During the wetter months, there are small streams or puddles that require traversing but usually a board is setup. The parking lot is small but it's conveniently placed adjacent to an ice cream shop. Dog owners visit regularly and good boys are often unleashed, so expect a darty(dog party). There is no bathroom or porta potty available.

Several good primary trials with a few streams for the pups. We have a regular 4.5 mile walk,  and a 2 mile walk mapped out. Following the marked trail i believe is about 3.5 mile loop. Makings at the water plant crossing could be better for those unfamiliar with the dog leg trail across the driveway. One of our favorite trails.
Pretty roots trip hazards but nice quiet dog friendly trails.

Free to non residents on weekdays, only resident parking on weekends. This is a fabulous beach that I love taking toddlers to. The water is shallow with no waves so it's fun for finding hermit crabs and seashells. It's rocky so definitely wear appropriate footwear. I also would try to refrain from visiting at the end of July as the greenhead flies are pretty prominent.

Electronic sign indicated Resident Only parking on Sat/Sun only. I arrived at 11:45 on a Thurs mid-June and had no problem getting a parking spot. The beach is right there, so very easily accessed. No bathroom or facilities.
By the time I left at 2, it was packed. Lots of kids and families enjoying some beach time. Beautiful soft sand, chilly water, and a view that made me think I was in Florida!
This is a beach for locals.  There's not much sand, except at low tide.  The flying teeth (Greenhead flies) are bad in July.
A small local beach for local residents only. Car will be ticketed if not having the town sticker.

Nice spot to sit and relax. Residents only, but you can park and sit if not.
Water is more for wading than swimming, due to how shallow it is, but it's a great spot to sit and work remote or relax. Love it here.
Amazing view and pretty clean and clear water , quite spot too
Busy small beach with a nice view. Parking is very limited on a busy day nearly impossible.
Pavillion Beach is a great little beach with easy access parking.  No bathrooms and no snack bar.  A little rocky and immediately adjacent to an active boat ramp.
From the pictures I see I can only imagine five stars I hope .
Best place on earth.

A tad thickly settled at the outset you may feel like you're sneaking thru someone's backyard. Perfectly manicured yards quickly give way to some fairly gnarly steeps for Ipswich. Purported to be the highest undeveloped terrain in the 356, this former pasture has some serious trees. "Hilltop" lake alone is worth the trek. The thorns are starting to encroach on the path in some locations and I didn't see any turkeys, but still two thumbs up.
Beautiful hiking area.  Some steep incline and gentle level areas.  Mind the stones and roots.  Lovely shaded trails.

An amazing place to walk, hike, and mountain bike. Miles and miles of awesome singletrack. This is where I grew up mountain biking. I feel so lucky to have been given access to this park and it's amazing dirt!

Willowdale State Forest is very large and spreads from both sides of route 1 and the paths throughout the woods can take you from town to town so make sure to have a map of some sort. The side near Marini Farm in Ipswich is great for mountain biking snow, rain, or shine.
Good trails and small hills.  Look out for mountain bikers.  The mosquitos are healthy.

Huge reserve with tons of trails.  We hike here often and almost never walk the same set of trails twice.  There is always something new to see or a new entry to try.  Lots of variation from wetland to old growth pine forest to riverside and open field.  We see horses, bikers, hikers, and runners.  Highly recommended.  Most of the trails are identified by numbered intersections. The trails themselves vary in difficulty and range from singletrack to pavement. There's no good trail map at the trail heads so it's recommended to download the map to your phone before you go.
Hiking trails need some attention but overall, the forest trails are interesting and varied.
Good variety of trails and access roads, good for a beginner like me or a more advanced rider.
Nice trails, a lot of different routes to explore and maps are available at the entrance most of the time. It's very popular with bikers but also Is suitable for easy flat trail walking
Great place to explore and also connect to Bradley Palmer State Park.

place_name: Ipswich Town and Country Garden Club
review_text: Lindo amei
The GPS point attached to this is not the Crane Wildlife Refuge. We never wound up finding where to enter!
Great place to take my dog for a walk

2 stars for trying to conserve land with the greenbelt but should be 0 for preserving history and cultures that contributed already by dramatizing with Salem Witch trials in the description. Seems as though there were others with the name "How" but with an "e" at the end. Also Wicca and Wicans associated with Salem Witches were first used as derogatory term towards rural Welsh/Celtic who weaved with Willow branches by Urban progressives. A brief reference to Willow made for this culture with the first land grab and named Willowdale State Forest down the street.
I'm guessing Hollywood only pays for the art classes in stage design and ambiance if the story contains more drama. Close enough I guess and now I know why Transference is a thing in psychology courses.
A little over a mile trail loop through the woods close to surrounding houses there unfortunately wasn't much to see.

Firstly, kudos for someone plowing the parking lot at Echo. It should be noted however that there are not two parking options as indicated on the trail map [at least not in winter]. Entering the echo property is sub optimal as you cannot escape the feeling that you're traipsing through local backyards [see Turkey Hill]. The main trail takes you through some exceptional old growth forest, but the featured swamp is thickly settled with homes and appears bereft of beaver.
Very scenic and relaxing. Well maintained trails.
This is really just a trail through the woods. It's nice, but I wouldn't call this a "conservation area". Still, for what it is, it's very nice. Substantial bridges, enjoyable views.
Lots of mountain bikers.
Great time

Centrally located in the heart of town the newly monickered 'middle green' is everything you look for in a quaint New England lawn. Visitor center, River Walk, monuments and random portico's are all at a stone's throw. Possibly too close to law enforcement for some.
Great job by Ipswich to create such a great space for the children of Ipswich Youth Soccer to call these fields their home field.
Flat [as these things go], lush and spacious
Nice needs a vendor for food
Great space for town sports
Short trail but well maintained with an observation deck off of it.  Worth the walk if you enjoy watching birds

The parking lot 5 connect to 2 trial one to beach and the other is the pine trial that connect the marsh land then circulated back to parking lot 4. Both trial is nice walk with broad walk or soft sand. Particular pleasant at late summer afternoon when most people at beach this is a place to gain a sense of solitude .

A quaint trail system with an observation deck that has seating and mounted binoculars. I highly recommend this spot to anybody who wants to observe osprey once they have completed their migration to this location. There have been osprey returning to this perch to nest and raise a clutch every year for the past six years, and it's a wonderful experience to watch the clumsy hatchlings grow into capable diving birds of prey.

Osprey have always been my main attraction to this particular spot, however, you will have a chance of seeing many other birds from this observation tower. Harriers, peregrines, kestrels, egrets, herons, bitterns, cormorants, finches, and much more occasionally make a pass-by this location.

Early mornings and late afternoons are the best time to witness the highest levels of activity, like most locations at this wildlife refuge.

The Pines trail is awesome. Handicapped access makes this a special trail to see woodland and songbirds ESPECIALLY in the coming weeks. Travel slow and listen you will hear the birds 1st then see them. Great photo opps exist here for the patient birder. The observation deck provides expansive marsh views. The post to the right of the osprey nesting platform is always a perfect place for patching eagles, hawks and falcons!
Note: parking lot is small so be patient also pick up a single piece of trash if you can, unfortunately our other nature lovers aren't so kind and leave alot behind...Enjoy!
Absolutely love Parker River National Wildlife Refuge if which the Pines Trail is just one part of it. So much serenity and wildlife as well as various trails to walk.
Short, easy trail.  Sit at the various benches.  Patience will let the birds come into view.

A nice little section of pine forest, with a deck overlooking a large tidal saltmarsh.

Nice part of PRNWR on Plumb Island.
Short and sweet handicap accessible easy trail loop .3 miles total.

Decent park. I have a lot of memories here meeting a ton of friends here. The flow is decent and you can meet some great people. The park itself is okay but lacks in room. The main thing people skate is the manual pad and the half pipe really needs to be redone. But overall nice park for any skill level.
Skatelite and metal ramps tucked into the park. Has a mini ramp, manual pad, and a few other ok features.
I remember going to this skatepark 12-13 years ago and there were a bunch of bully kids that made the skatepark unpleasant. Hopefully the park is better now.
The board walk is in great shape. Plenty of parking and bathrooms that aren't portapodies. It's a great way to spend the day or an afternoon for five bucks. They also accept national park passes.

A great trail! This walk is mostly on a boardwalk with a bit of elevation gain. Gives you great views of not only the marsh but the ocean as well. It is part of a nature reserve and requires $5 per private vehicle. Well worth it though and you can check out the other beach areas at the park!

Nice boardwalk trail that takes you I to the wetlands and along the dunes. The round trip length is about 1 mile or so.  Some nice lookout spots along the way.  This includes the fire tower overlooking the wetlands.
Very picturesque. Very short trail. If you live close by it's definitely worth a drive. Be sure to pack bug spray and leave your dog at home despite whatever other reviews might say.
Parking can be difficult. Its a nice short trail that is wheel chair accessible. It would be better if the maintenance road was available to walk along to the area where the restrooms are.

Certainly one of the best hiking paths on plum island. The hellcat trails offers a both wooded and marshy scenery to the west and a hilly dune path to the east. Worth hiking both paths for sure! You're bound to see a wide variety of birds and hearty sand vegetation!

Part of the Parker River National Wildlife Refuge, this well designed and platform trail made for a pleasant walk that led to areas with great  views. Wheelchair accessible. $5 entrance fee to the refuge. I recommend a visit!
Parking [P] can be a bit of a challenge in terms of finding a spot.
Very nice loop trail that takes in sights of marshes and dunes by seashore.

I was finally able to stop by the distillery, and chose their Distillers Drawer release to do so. SImply an amazing American rum rivalling unadulterated Caribbean rums. For rums that have not aged 10+ years as of yet, could have fooled me. They sip just fine!! Andrew Cabot the founder poured for my tastings and I received some great rum history. It was also great to meet Maggie Campbell. This is a serious rum.

Stopped in on Saturday to try some rum and check out the place.  They've truly pulled out all the stops.  The tasting room is really nice with a large sail boat turned into the bar.  The staff was just wonderful and did a great job taking us through the tasting.  Plan ahead if you want to take a tour.  You can book that on their web site.  The rum we had was outstanding and we left with a bottle and a plan to take friends back for a tour in the near future.  Highly recommend you check the place out.

An absolute treasure. Some of the best rums around, remarkable for being so young. The Navy Yard and the queens share are outstanding. Seek out their limited releases, typically hand picked barrels that really shined. Their head distiller Maggie is also delightful. Do yourself a favor and set up a tour!

Great local distillery. If you are serious about rum, they make some of the best around. Not around the North Shore but around the world. The people here are both very friendly and exceptional at their craft. People on rum forums are jealous of us who can purchase it here in Mass. If you get a chance to go to a Distiller's Drawer event do not pass it up.

Both the Amber and Navy Yard rums impress, but for different reasons. The Amber is the best tasting rum I've ever had (I've had a few). The Navy Yard has the taste, and body, to be the standout in a dark and stormy, reminding that the drink is about the spirits in it.

The finest rum in the world. Tour guides are themselves experts on all things about the history of rum, the fabrication process and the current rum market. Blown away by how informative and how impressive this company and its employees are.

Privateer is doing an exceptional job--they take their time with the distilling process, and their products speak for themselves. I would highly suggest taking a tasting tour of their factory; you'll wonder why you ever put up with rum that was anything lesser.
I thought I knew about rum, but this tour was an education, Got to taste some exquisite rums and went home with a bottle of Navy Yard. Great way to spend and hour and a bit.
Love Ipswich traffic can be bad at times but lots of things to do and see. Fun shops and events. Lots of places to walk and bike.
Great town. Historical, water centric, good eats and coffee.
Warning: don't think about parking your filthy out of town car here. They made the lot residents only and it comes with a $30 ticket.
Ebsco Corporate Park, formerly known as the town of Ipswich has decided to solve the parking problem they created by giving all town land to Ebsco by banning out of towners from parking here.
When Cold , its cold very windy no real shelter.clean seating
Nice little train stop. Trains always on time.
Calm and peaceful town.
Esta estacion te conecta hacia Boston-Newburyport y Rockport. Hay estacionamiento y centrica locacion.
review_translated_text: This station connects you to Boston-Newburyport and Rockport. There is parking and a central location.

review_text: We attended a book author's event. Beautiful facility with excellent staff.
response_from_owner_text: Thank you, Daniel! We are so pleased you enjoyed your experience at the Club!

review_text: Place is beautiful.  Great for functions or becoming a member

Outstanding conditions and design.  Staff and facilities are excellent.
Grounds crew is very talented, and it shows in every aspect of the course.
A real treat!
response_from_owner_text: Thank you for the kind words and excellent rating. We love our team and we are so pleased that you enjoyed your time on the course!

review_text: Beautiful homes. Nice clubhouse.
response_from_owner_text: Thank you for the kind feedback, Connie! Please visit us again soon.

review_text: This is a great golf experience . The golf staff are top notch. When you walk in the pro shop, everyone is smiling and attentive . That was a great start to the day . The golf course is in fantastic shape and a great challenge for good golfers . I didn't play well but the scenery and conditions made up for my terrible golf game

Had a bad experience at the entrance of the building. Cars couldn't go thru because both lanes were blocked with a working truck and local carts.
Drivers had to backup all the way after dropping off people. Awfull!
Other than that everything was great. Awesome wedding!

We enjoyed an elegant rehearsal dinner on the balcony terrace. The elevated setting was gorgeous, bar and table service impecable, and the food was absolutely delicious! A perfect location for any event

Played a round with the family on a Saturday afternoon. Went it at 3.30 pm and the course was practically empty. Wonderful, but narrow, course in amazing condition. Every hole had something interesting, like a raised green, placement tee shot, or forced carry. Loved it and will definitely come back.

It's quiet, peaceful, and scenic.  This part of this river is surprisingly good as a swimming hole. There are picnic tables and large campsites, and any passing boaters are allowed to picnic.  The picnic/camping area is a large open shaded area under pine trees next to a river shore.

I have to take off a star because the fee is a bit high for a primitive camping site that is only accessible by canoe or kayak.  This year it's $32 per family for a membership then $10 a person per night up to $25 per night.  So if you want to try camping one night it would cost a couple $52.  Yes, the money goes to Massachusetts Audubon which is a good cause.  But it's free for anyone to picnic during the day.
Beautiful.  Easy paddling to get there.

Public way with a 'Keep Out' vibe. Don't know the specifics of the political horse trading that went on behind the scenes (but if it was similar to the Raymond fields scam this feels right), but the upshot is a walk through a bucolic pasture littered with scolding signage. Not my particular cup of tea.
Excellent beer and food! The clam chowder was delicious. Fish tacos were hough with several flavor profiles coming together to form a party in your mouth.

Large capacity brewpub off the beaten path in Ipswich, MA. Offer a variety of their beers and a standard pub menu---not exciting, but you come here for the beer, not Haut Cuisine. Appetizers of a soft pretzel and the baked brie.  Both very good. Then a Brewers Burger and Fish & Chips.  Good burger. Fish (Haddock) dry---most likely because it was still frozen when breaded and fried. As beer drinkers, we came to sample a few of their beers. My son had the American Lager. Standard, but good. I had the Dark Ale. Disappointing. Bitter. Not good bitter as in British and German ales, but unpleasantly bitter with a lingering aftertaste. Good service. Not sure we'd come again.

Beautiful night out on the deck with our puppies. Food came out quick, friendly, attentive servers. Menu is diverse with a few gluten-free and generally healthy options. Everything we ordered was delicious. Those tater tots were perfectly crunchy. Tried a new beer and was not disappointed.

I hosted my husband's 40th surprise party here, and it was amazing. Planning the party was a breeze, and the venue was the perfect location given the barn door made for a great surprise unveiling. Myles and team were so accommodating, and they helped me plan the mixer finger food and samplers which was also very budget friendly. They were also super helpful with the set up before the party.  And during the event, the wait staff were super friendly and on point throughout. Everyone at the party only had positive things to say. And the food and drinks were fantastic! Exceeded my expectations in every way. Thanks for making the vision a reality!

This has been my boyfriend & I's go to spot since we've moved here. A night or two out at Ipswich Ale has quickly fallen into our weekly routine. Great beer & food & even better staff. Myles & Alexis never fail to take the time to catch up with us even if they are working a busy dining area & always make for the full experience of stopping in for a night out. If sours are your jam checkout whichever they currently have in rotation-- highly recommend! Definitely worth a visit or many.

Fantastic little brewery. Excellent beers and the food was really good as well. The Ipswich pilsner was one of the better pilsners I've had here. Light and refreshing and the chucktoberfest was very good too.

The harvest flatbread was savory and delicious. Service was excellent and our waitress was awesome.
5 stars!
Nice brew selection and a very nice menu as well, including several options for non-meat eaters. The vegan chili was fabulous. I will definitely go back whenever I am in the area.

I thought this place was great. Lots of people where here today. There were outside seating and indoor seating, at the time we got there 1:30pm there was a wait list for the outdoor seating so we sat inside. The place was very clean and well staffed. The bar was open, and we had a great waitress. The food was good, not the best but definitely good. We got two appetizers and three main dishs, they didn't have diet coke or any diet soda which was a bunmer, so we settled with water.

This is such a humble studio and community for what it actually is which I think makes it that much more special. The owner and the tenured teachers are EXTREMELY experienced and well-trained. Almost all of them offer thoughtful and intentional assists and adjustments rather than sitting at the front of the class just demonstrating the poses. The students have beautiful practices and are welcoming to all newcomers. The view of the river is so serene. Lack of mirrors helps you really turn inward. I just wish they had more classes-- both in quantity/times offered and in types of yoga. But this is the best yoga studio on the North Shore, hands down!
Wonderful class with Kelly this morning. Her heart is big, she made me feel right at home! Thank you!
Beautiful yoga studio, located on the river, with a warm, welcoming vibe. Loved my class with Julie, and look forward to visiting again!

The Procter Estate is a park seemingly without an entrance. I guess it is primarly designed for local walkers. You might think that you can gain access from the soccer parking lot, but you would be incorrect. Unless you're prepared to jump a fence and bushwack thru the pucker brush you need to walk back to 1A and travle down the sidewalk until you see the trailhead. Nice pastureland topograhpy with swans.

I visited this place a few days ago and it was amazing! You have the option to sit outside, however it was very hot out so we sat inside. The place has a Viking theme to it. The server / bar tender was very friendly and was very knowledgeable with each product they offered. The one down side to this place is that it is very small and can get busy fast. Overall, I had a great time and I definitely recommend going!

Stopped by for an afternoon tasting after discovering 1634 at a local concert event. It was a beautiful spring day to sit out under the awnings provided, and Matt was prompt in welcoming our group and presenting our tasting options. We decided to try the flights for $12 which included a 6 sample variety. Matt was thorough and explained our flights with great detail, which we appreciated! We all enjoyed the samples and had a tough time choosing our favorites.

We also met the owner, Dan, who was friendly and happy to share his passion, answer our questions, and told us more about their operation. Both Matt and Dan were gracious hosts and made our afternoon enjoyable!

They also have a small bar inside for tastings year round. We all left with a bottle to bring home, and would certainly return. Highly recommend stopping by for a tasting and to pick up a bottle of their many offerings!

Best mead in New England! Small spot in downtown Ipswich with some patio seats out front. The owner breaks the menu down from dry to sweet, which makes it easier to find flavor pallets. Additionally, they are super knowledgeable and will happily answer any questions you may have! Many of their ingredients are locally grown, so if you are a supporter of small businesses, give them a try!

Chance visit as we drove by and glad we stopped. Did a flight of 6 each (pre-selected) and enjoyed all of the 6. Nice taste and flavor pairings. Got a nice education on meads and just enjoyed the product

We had an amazing time here! We went on a Sunday afternoon in July and it was quiet, so we had the chance to talk for a long while with one of the staff. They were so kind and answered our questions about their mead and the process of making it. The tasting flight was a great way to taste 6 of their current meads and get a sense of the difference flavor profiles. Definitely needs to be on your list of stops in Ipswich, MA!
response_from_owner_text: Thank you Stefanie for your feedback.  We were glad you had a good visit, and we are lucky to have great staff members!

review_text: They have a nice selection of meads from dry to very sweet.
response_from_owner_text: Thank you for your feedback! Glad you enjoyed the mead!

review_text: Excellent assortment of meads and the tour was very insightful. I went to the meadery with three others and we got to try about 6-7 different types of mead. We used a Groupon which included the tasting, glasses and a tour. Will be returning for more mead in the future. We even bought a couple of bottles to bring home!

Small, but very interesting place. Never tried Mead before, but I got a great introduction to it, Emma took me through the different varieties, then gave me a tour of the fermentation area. I got to meet Dan the owner, got to use the corking device and even got to put wax on a bottle to seal it! Overall very nice time was had, and I brought home three varieties to enjoy.
response_from_owner_text: Thanks for trying mead for the first time, and glad you enjoyed it!

review_text: This is a very nice park. They have a lot of fields and a lot of room for a lot of activity. We were there for the Special Olympics events that were being held on that day but I think it's a fantastic place to have them. The track is nice and made for running and the long jump pit had plenty of really nice sand. All the kids had a fantastic time that day and the weather was perfect. We appreciate being able to have the games there. Thank you.

We were baby sitting our friend's two year old daughter and took her here. She absolutely loved it. There's something for all ages there. The swings are nice. The whole play center is really neat and well put together. I wish I had this park when I was a kid.
Bialek Park is a fun place to bring the kids. It has different play structures than most of the playgrounds in the area. Love the tables with a big umbrella over them. Fairly well maintained.

Decent playground, but the choice of the town to make it a "carry in, carry out" park has caused it to look terrible, with trash and plastic cups and bottles everywhere.  I had to tell my two year old to put down trash a number of times .  Put two trash barrels in, and have the city truck come by once every two days to pick up.
not upkept well, no one follows the take in take out rule, therefore trash everywhere!! Sad being that its a cute park close to to many homes and great location!!!
Wonderful park with lots of age options and mobility options for kids! If there are games going the concession stand is great, and if there aren't there are fields the kids can run on!

Great park. The grandsons had ball. However, some I'll bred jerks left a lot of trash behind. I suspect teen partiers. The park is not open after dark, and police patrols should prevent this. Bring an idiot stick, gloves, and a trash bag.
It's a decent ball field. Not a lot of fan seating and no home run line.
Awesome service best produce
response_from_owner_text: Hi Paul, thanks for the 5 star review but we don't sell produce!  Maybe you mixed us up with Northern Lights Farmstand just down the road?

review_text:
Gretchen Mello is the best riding instructor ever !!! Extremely educated about horses and Dressage. Strong but gentle takes the time to help you learn so you can succeed.
Best experience ever!
Thank you Gretchen
Valerie 1992
Nice, good place
Short trail along a field and through the woods it connects to the rest of the trails in Willowdale. I didn't see much wildlife besides a few birds.
